posts.title: #1 Strong Opinions, Loosely Held
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
Hiya,


I guess weâ€™re doing it. Iâ€™ve wanted to start one of these babies for months now, but my incompetencies have been holding me in check. I have little snippets I collect (from books and articles) that I find interesting, and always thinkâ€¦ ah, this would be so cool to talk about with someone.


But I donâ€™t.


The thing is, I donâ€™t know enough. I can barely remember the name of a single author. The philosophical theories I consider for days, I would never be able to tell you whoâ€™s behind them. But Iâ€™m so curious.

And so Iâ€™m now trying to design my life in a way that the values I care about can fully express themselves. I care about people, connections, passion, thinking, having a meaningful life and maximising little pleasures.


Iâ€™m also starting to accept the ego-driven side of putting yourself on the internet. Itâ€™s inevitable if you want to connect at scale, so Iâ€™m going to stop fighting it, and try to make it as genuine and interesting as I can.


So, letâ€™s do it.


I really hope youâ€™ll find something interesting/inspiring/heartwarming in this email every Sunday. Canâ€™t wait to properly start.


Thanks so much for joining me (I canâ€™t believe you did!!!) and I hope you have a wonderful week!


Liz xx

posts.title: #2 Your Discomfort Zone Will Kill You
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
Heya,


Itâ€™s been an emotional week on my end. I will admit Iâ€™ve spent as much time tracking my YouTube subscribers as breathing. At 10,000 subs, I reached milestones I never even dreamed of. And I felt just absolute terror.


It really doesnâ€™t make sense. Iâ€™ve seen Instagram photos of people with balloons of 1K, 50K, 1M. Smiling, excited, overjoyed. Celebrating. So why is it that all I felt was fear?


We are told that our comfort zone will kill us. That we should aim for more. That happiness and meaning comes after working hard and achieving things.


Well, I found that the discomfort zone of â€˜achievementâ€™ is just as painful. When you first get there, itâ€™s just imposter syndrome. You want to cry (which I did), quit and leave. Just as much as you did when you were in your comfort zone before starting.


But this is so liberating. Itâ€™s terrible either way: not doing anything, or going for what youâ€™re scared of. So you might as well try. Life will always suck one way or another. But itâ€™s worth some small highs.


And once you get used to that new place of discomfort, it starts becoming less so. Weâ€™re hardwired to be weary and scared of somewhere new. But once they become familiar, perhaps we can say â€˜Hey, this isnâ€™t a big deal.â€™ And we keep moving forward.


I anticipate the next milestones on this online journey will be less shocking. Maybe youâ€™ll even see me smile with a cake one day.


So what are you holding back from, what is the dream discomfort zone youâ€™re avoiding?

Wishing you a wonderful week,

Liz xx


Full post here

posts.title: #3 Why You Should Listen To Your Lazy Self
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
Iâ€™m a scheduling queen.


Seriously, I just love that fresh-new-project feeling, time-blocking, organising a calendar, or bullet journal with what my inspired self feels like imaging my life will start to look like. The issue is, Iâ€™m not always my inspired self.


Too often Iâ€™m my lazy self. I canâ€™t stop scrolling. I cba to stick to things when that early excitement fades.

And so Iâ€™ve found most things I start, I completely just stop.


I donâ€™t know why it took me so long to (accidentally) figure out, that if I was scheduling things for my lazy self, the chances of me failing came down to basically zero.


When inspired I could overwork and go ahead on my schedule.

When lazy I could to the bare minimum I scheduled.

And when particularly unproductive, Iâ€™m always always in the buffer-zone of â€˜I probably have done too much at some point to not fall behind nowâ€™.


Itâ€™s amazing.


And itâ€™s not just being generous with my scheduling time, I create whole systems of work that improve when Iâ€™m unproductive.


My creative work benefits from breakthroughs I get when in the shower or daydreaming in bed. (So I start this work, identify key problems, and just let it be).


My second brain benefits from drafts not being categorised, because even if I get around to it 6 months later, Iâ€™m much more likely to have a fresh perspective.


My study schedules are a combination of up-until-2am on a topic I love, and a weeks of not touching lecture notes because Iâ€™m not in the mood.


Iâ€™m working consistently, but on a longer time-scale, never stopping things that are important to me. Rather than coming up with some ridiculous â€˜rigid and consistentâ€™ plan, that I ultimately drop altogether.


Iâ€™d really recommend doing this more intentionally :)


Full article here :)

posts.title: #4 Why I don't trust myself when running
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
I find it really funny when I say â€˜this just isnâ€™t for meâ€™ or when I quit things. I so confidently trust Elizabeth when everything points to me really not being a reliable person.


Iâ€™ve changed so much over the past 5 years, even over this last year alone. Things I used to enjoy I now hate and vice versa.


So, should I trust myself?


I think, in many ways: absolutely not. Let me explain.


I used to see things in a way that they are or arenâ€™t enjoyable. But then I thinkâ€¦ some people enjoy running. They seriously find putting on trainers and going out to pant in the cold, fun. Some even run marathons or triathlons or iron men (look it up ðŸ˜¬).


So how do I account for that?


Benjamin Hardy, one of my favourite psychologists said: You can get yourself to want anything, so you might as well be intentional in what you get yourself to enjoy.


I now very much subscribe to this idea - I will start liking things (just as people do running) if I push past that initial hard stage, and donâ€™t trust how much I hate it at first.


And things that are really worth doing, are worth pushing through. I put off YouTube for years because I was so scared to put myself out there, and now (excluding the tears) it is really one of the funnest things I do.


So I donâ€™t trust myself. I donâ€™t think that people who run are too different to me, because Iâ€™m so different to myself to start with.


I feel I have some responsibility to create myself through the decisions I make and environments I choose. And as Benjamin would say: youâ€™ll find, you have been creating yourself all along, even if unintentionally.


So I might as well be intentional about it.


Full article here :)

posts.title: #5 Why It Sucks To Be Human
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
Heya,


Itâ€™s almost 12am and Iâ€™d completely forgotten about todayâ€™s newsletter. So itâ€™s going to be a short one. I was filming a video today and in researching for it, I got reminded of a really cool concept.


That humans are the only creatures that can hate themselves.


Friedrich Nietzsche talks about this in the Geneaology of Morals, one of my favourite philosophical essays. Although he elaborates on this a lot more (I have a summary of the book here), I find that realisation alone to have me thinking.


I wonder why and how itâ€™s so hard for us to accept ourselves.


Animals donâ€™t hate their bodies. They donâ€™t hate their predatory nature. They donâ€™t hate their feathers or their skin.


It wouldâ€™ve probably been endlessly easier to be anything else. Why does self-love come so hard to humans?


Apologies for the weird prompt - but I wonder if realising this helps you too?


Hope you have an amazing week,

Liz


Full article here :)

posts.title: #6 Depression and Games
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
Heya,


One of my favourite quotes from one of my favourite people in the world Naval Ravikant is:

The opposite of play isnâ€™t work. Itâ€™s depression.


This hit me hard. I feel Iâ€™d always thought of things as either work or play. Was I doing â€˜me thingsâ€™ or was I â€˜workingâ€™. When I was younger I couldnâ€™t wait to finish homework so I could watch TV.


Things were always phrased in such a way that I could â€˜rest and have funâ€™ once Iâ€™d done my â€˜workâ€™.


But the thing is, they arenâ€™t two sides of the same spectrum, and realising this was life-changing.

The opposite of fun isnâ€™t work, itâ€™s misery (or as Naval puts it, depression).


And work sits somewhere in between, depending on the task. I job I hate is more on the misery side and a task I love is close to, or even fully - play.


So when I find myself in a state of flow and â€˜workingâ€™ for 20h in a row, fully content, inspired and happy - itâ€™s not because Iâ€™ve become and different person and I hate play.


Itâ€™s because to me, I am playing.


So thatâ€™s become my goal. To find things that look like work, pay like work, qualify as work, but that feel fully like play.


Itâ€™s amazing how â€˜successfulâ€™ one suddenly becomes.

Wishing you an amazing week,

Love,

Liz


Full article here :)

posts.title: #7 How I deal with my emotions
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
Iâ€™m an emotional person. I get passionate about inanimate objects like books and courses Iâ€™m signed up for. And often the results arenâ€™t pretty.


One thing has massively changed how I manage my negative emotional responses. Itâ€™s something that seems so blatantly obvious, that I donâ€™t know why I hadnâ€™t realised it before:


Dividing my feelings into two types: primary or secondary emotions.


Let me explain. Primary emotions are those that I feel in direct response to something. I fail - so I feel bad. I hurt someone - so I feel guilty. I get shouted at - so I feel sad. I donâ€™t get a response from a friend - so I feel abandoned.


I now see primary emotions as normal, healthy, human, justified, evolutionary responses to what happens in the world.


Secondary emotions are those that kill me. I donâ€™t study for 2 days so I feel guilty, but then I feel frustrated at myself for feeling guilty. I fail at something and feel bad - but then I feel angry for feeling sad when I should rather be working. Someone does something mean and I feel hurt - and then I feel sad for letting it get to me.


Secondary emotions are bull**t. While the primary ones are a normal response, the secondary ones are overthinking gone wild.


Primary emotions donâ€™t last long. Think of it, how long can you feel pure burning anger for? Probably 5 minutes max. But I can probably feel guilty for being so angry for weeks later.


Secondary emotions donâ€™t go away easily. They stick, and they spiral. I canâ€™t really spiral into a primary emotion, itâ€™s more raw and temporary. But I can brew and brew and fall deeper and deeper into secondary self-hate, anger or sadness.


So I donâ€™t tolerate a secondary emotion, and fully lean into my primary ones.


When Iâ€™m feeling bad - I try to identify what it really is. Sadness? Loneliness? Anger? Hurt? Guilt? I let it do its thing, thereâ€™s probably a reason for it.


But the second I realise what Iâ€™m feeling is a secondary emotion: anger for being sad, guilt for feeling lonely, I stop right there. I ignore the secondary emotion, I go back to the first, and let it run its 3 or 5 minute course, and move on with my day.


It has been life changing.


I would love to hear if this sounds mad or if youâ€™ve known it all along.

Hoping you have an amazing week,

Love,

Liz xx


Full article here :)

posts.title: #8 Why I'm OK with being mediocre
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
Iâ€™ve changed.


Iâ€™ve just realised, Iâ€™ve gone from a â€œnever show your work until itâ€™s perfectâ€ kind of person, to a â€œput things out anyways and cry if you mustâ€ kind of person. And itâ€™s been incredible.


Iâ€™ve been programmed to only produce â€˜goodâ€™ work. To do my research first. To practice until perfect. Iâ€™m so scared of people seeing sub-par work. Of people thinking Iâ€™m embarrassing, or stupid, or the worst of the worst: that I donâ€™t know just how mediocre my work is.


Because I really do.


But one of the best things Iâ€™ve ever heard about this, is Seth Godinâ€™s response to someone asking him why they just werenâ€™t very good at writing.


His answer: â€œShow me your bad work.â€


And they had nothing to show. Iâ€™ve often been in the same position. I do spend a lot of time thinking about things I want to do, scared that if I tried I wouldnâ€™t be good - but not actually trying.


And it seems so simple and obvious: but how do I expect to improve if I donâ€™t put out terrible work first?


You can tell a lot about how good someone is at what they do by how much terrible work theyâ€™ve already produced.


So knowing this, reminding myself of this, convincing myself that things are guaranteed to improve if you just keep working, is the way I see things now.


My mantra: keep producing work you hate, until you start producing work you love.

Hope you have a great week!

Love,

Liz xx


Full article here :)

posts.title: #9 I'm a horrible person
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
Iâ€™ve been a terrible friend for the last few weeks.


And no, nothingâ€™s changed. Iâ€™ve acted the same as I always do, the only difference is, this time it was with new people. And it just highlighted how messed up some of my behaviour is.


I usually never go to people with problems. If youâ€™re the same - youâ€™re happy to give randomers 2h of your life to talk about their issues, but blank your friends for weeks when youâ€™re not feeling ok, refusing to open up - I hope this helps.


My previous thought process: I couldnâ€™t waste someoneâ€™s time with my issues. My problems are my fault. I donâ€™t have â€˜realâ€™ problems, Iâ€™ll go to others when I really need to.


Well if you, like me, thought youâ€™re such a generous, good human for sparing others your woes, let me just tell you: weâ€™re both selfish tw*ts.


Itâ€™s not generous to spare others my problems - itâ€™s my ego thinking I need â€˜biggerâ€™ ones to actually make a big deal out of.


That others might think Iâ€™m weak, stupid, immature, emotional (when we all know Iâ€™m too often all of those things).


That my friends might suddenly realise the poor choices I make, how vulnerable I am sometimes, that Iâ€™m spending all day thinking about just myself.


But thatâ€™s all absolutely fine.


How much freer would I feel if my friends knew how vulnerable and immature I can be? If they knew that I was crying?


How much more mature would I be if I admitted that itâ€™s my perfectionist ego holding me back and not my generosity?


So Iâ€™ve admitted it. And honestly, Iâ€™ve flipped the switch. The good thing about my self-directed anger is that it does always allow me to implement immediate and permanent changes. And so Iâ€™m no longer going to be tw*t. Iâ€™m going to people with problems asap, not 4 weeks later.


Hereâ€™s an honest sorry to all my friends in the past, and one in the present in particular.

Hoping you all have a great week,

Liz xx


Full article here :)

posts.title: #10 This is not a safe space
posts.author: Lizzie
posts.content:
Iâ€™ve had years of training for welfare. To create comfortable, accepting, non-judgemental spaces for discussions to occur. A â€˜safeâ€™ space, or a â€˜braveâ€™ space.


So you can imagine my shock when I was listening to a podcast wherein the invitee, someone I massively respected thus far, said he didnâ€™t believe in safe spaces. That he didnâ€™t have them in his relationship, or at his workplace.


As â€˜thank God Iâ€™m not his wifeâ€™ as that sounded at first, I will admit, it took me about 10 seconds to come around to agreeing with him. Letâ€™s see if I can do the same here. (worth listening to the whole podcast though, itâ€™s so good!)


In long-term relationships: with family, partners, colleagues, he argued that itâ€™s worth sacrificing emotional cushioning for real honesty.


â€œIn being honest, weâ€™re going to be direct, weâ€™re going to say harsh things - in the spirit of â€˜I want to lift you up, I want to see you get betterâ€™.â€


And I will say that I love that. I believe Iâ€™ve often gone too much in the whole other direction of â€˜I must be fully kind, polite and supportive for someone to feel OKâ€™.


And while noone is arguing for rude honesty, thereâ€™s perhaps something to be said for consensual, respectful honesty.


The type that tells you youâ€™ve not been great and that youâ€™ve made poor choices when you ask. The type that accepts you at the not-so-great times and is honest about wanting a change. The type that supports and believes in improvements while accepting and calling the present what it is: sometimes not amazing.

And furthermore, this attitude gives full credibility to compliments when theyâ€™re there. To shared brainstorming for improvement. To support and trustworthiness. I will say, I am a fan.


Curious as to your thoughts!

Hoping you have an amazing week,

Liz xx
